Summary: The proposal aims to improve machine learning model robustness under distribution shifts by combining self-supervised pretraining, distributionally robust fine-tuning, and causal regularization. It targets out-of-distribution generalization, a significant challenge in real-world applications. The experimental plan includes standard benchmarks, synthetic data, large-scale pretraining, real-world deployment, and theoretical analysis.
Strengths: Clear and cohesive narrative linking problem to solution.
Innovative combination of self-supervised learning, DRO, and causal regularization.
Comprehensive experiment plan with multiple evaluation scenarios.
Strong scientific rigor with planned ablation studies and baseline comparisons.
Weaknesses: Lacks detail on computational cost and feasibility of large-scale pretraining.
Ambiguity in how latent feature clustering in DRO will be implemented.
Real-world deployment study is ambitious without clear implementation details.
Limited discussion of potential risks and mitigation strategies.
Questions: How will the computational cost of large-scale pretraining be managed?
What specific techniques will be used for latent feature clustering in DRO?
Can you provide more details on the implementation of the real-world deployment study?
How will the proposed method compare to other recent approaches not mentioned in the proposal (e.g., meta-learning for OOD generalization)?
Limitations: Potential high computational cost of large-scale pretraining.
Feasibility of latent feature clustering in DRO without domain annotations.
Generalizability of synthetic data experiments to real-world scenarios.
Theoretical analysis may not fully capture real-world complexities.
